Pigeon Pose primarily stretches the hip flexors, glutes, and deep hip rotators (like the piriformis) on the front leg, while lengthening the psoas of the back leg, improving hip mobility and releasing lower back tension. The movement pattern involves hip flexion (front leg) and extension (back leg) with external rotation of the front hip, requiring core stability and spinal support, making it a powerful hip opener. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked/Stretched 

• Front Leg (Bent): 

    • Glutes (Maximus, Medius, Minimus): Stretches the buttock muscles, aiding in hip extension and stability. 
    • Piriformis & Deep Hip Rotators: Releases tension in these muscles that rotate the thigh outward. 
    • Inner Thighs (Adductors): Helps to stabilize the leg. 

• Back Leg (Extended): 

    • Hip Flexors (Iliacus, Psoas): Lengthens these muscles at the front of the hip, crucial for stability and flexibility, especially after sitting. 
    • Quadriceps: A gentle stretch in the front of the thigh. 

• Core & Back: 

    • Spinal Erectors: Engaged to support the spine, especially in deeper variations. 
    • Core Muscles: Provide stability for the torso. [2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Hip Flexion & External Rotation (Front Leg): The front thigh bends and rotates outward in the hip socket. 
2. Hip Extension (Back Leg): The back leg extends straight behind you, lengthening the hip flexors. 
3. Spinal Stability & Flexion (Torso): The torso can remain upright (spinal extension) or fold forward (spinal flexion), requiring core engagement to maintain balance and support the lower back. [2, 5, 8, 9, 10, 11]  

Key Takeaway 
Pigeon Pose is a deep hip opener that targets flexibility and mobility in the glutes and hip flexors, making it excellent for relieving lower back pain and improving overall hip health, but it requires careful attention to knee and lower back alignment to avoid injury. [1, 2, 5, 6]
